data.description: Arman is a well-manicured Afghan male in his 40s who works as a cab driver. He speaks with a Farsi accent and carries himself with quiet dignity and genuine concern for others. Despite being treated dismissively and even rudely by his passenger, he remains composed, polite, and ultimately caring.
data.dialogue_summary: Arman speaks sparingly but meaningfully. He begins with deferential compliance ('Yes, sir.'), then asserts his honesty when accused of double-charging ('No, Miss. Nobody paid me.'). He gently checks on Dante's wellbeing ('Can I ask, are you okay?') and offers an unsolicited cultural reflection on male responsibility toward women. His dialogue is calm, accented, and dignified throughout, contrasting sharply with Dante's slurred aggression.

explicit_evidence.quote: Where I come from, a man would never let a woman come home alone like this. Always, you should have a good man with you.
Can I ask, are you okay?
Arman watches her with concern until she enters the building.

inferred_traits.rationale: Arman remains calm and polite despite being spoken to dismissively, called derogatory nicknames, and accused of dishonesty by an intoxicated passenger. He never retaliates or loses composure.
He insists he was not paid even when Dante assumes he was, suggesting he would not accept money he did not earn, even if it would have been easy to do so.
His response of laughing and saying 'OKAY' when Dante accuses him of tricks suggests a light, non-confrontational sense of humor in the face of absurdity.
His unsolicited comment about a man never letting a woman come home alone reflects deeply held cultural values around male responsibility and protection of women.
inferred_traits.trait: Traditional values regarding gender and protection
